At the facility, the areas are divided as followings:
Phase 1 Area:
The LPG (Propane & Butane) facility consists of a total of 25 bullet tanks, and one Sphere. 
The propane bullets facilities for Phase 1 consist of 10 bullet tanks located at north area of the plant. The total storage capacity of the bullets is 20,000 BBLS.
The LPG Facility has the capacity of trucks being loaded from the bullet tanks or sphere at a rate of 200 to 2,271.74 liters per minute.
The butane bullets facilities consist of 15 bullet tanks, and one Sphere, located at south area of the plant. Also, the 10 bullet tanks located at north area of the plant facilities can be used for butane storage. The total storage capacity of the bullets is 36,899 BBLS. 
Each bullet is connected to the dock's 10-inch pipeline for filling purpose and connected to butane pumps' 10-inch suction header. The sphere is connected also to the dock's 10-inch pipeline for filling purpose and connected to butane bullets filling pipeline for filling the butane bullets purpose. 
Butane is transferred from the bullets to the truck loading terminal and, eventually, to tank trucks for distribution to customers.
Butane and propane transfer rate from barges to bullet tanks or sphere is 1,000 gal/min.
Propane transfer rate from bullet to ship is 2,100 gal/min.

Executive Summary
                            Puerto Rico Energy, LLC
                            Puma Bayamon LPG Terminal
                            Risk Management Plan


Puerto Rico Energy, LLC (PR Energy), formerly Puma Energy Caribe, LLC (Puma) is currently performing butane and propane storage and truck loading activities at its terminal site located at State Road #28, km. 0.2, Bayamon, Puerto Rico.  Puma Energy Caribe, LLC changed name to Puerto Rico Energy, LLC but ownership and operations remain the same. The Terminal is using the Guaynabo Puerto Rico Energy dock facilities to receive and ship product. PR Energy is required to comply with United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68 because the facility stores propane and butane on-site in quantities exceeding the rule threshold quantity for these substances.  The following executive summary is provided in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.155.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
PR Energy is committed to operating and maintaining its butane and propane operations (generically referred to as liquefied petroleum gas or LPG) in a safe and responsible manner.  PR Energy has developed and implemented accidental release prevention and emergency response provisions at the facility, including those required under the USEPA RMP rule and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The facility is also subject to other emergency plan regulations such as those under the Oil Pollution Act (OPA) of 1990, state Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (ECPRA), and United States Coast Guard (USCG) rules.

General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The facility's general accident prevention program consists of compliance with USEPA's RMP and OSHA's PSM regulations. Key elements include the following:
Process Safety Information - Information regarding butane and propane hazards, process technology, and process equipment is complied, updated, and made available to operating personnel.
Process Hazard Analysis - Analyses are conducted every five years with the objective of identifying, evaluating, and controlling the process hazards, and findings and recommendations are promptly addressed.
Operating Procedures - Procedures are developed and maintained up to date to provide instructions for safe operations of process equipment during various phases of operation.
Training - Initial and recurring training is provided to all employees involved in operating a regulated process.
Mechanical Integrity - Procedures are developed and implemented to maintain the on-going integrity of vessels, process piping, transfer hoses, and other process equipment. These include procedures for maintenance, training of maintenance employees, and inspection and testing.
Management of

Change - Written procedures are used to manage changes to process-related chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures, and other changes that may affect a regulated process.
Pre-Startup Review - Reviews are conducted for new or significantly modified processes to ensure the facilities and processes are adequate and safe for operation.
Compliance Audits - Periodic audits are conducted at least every three years to verify compliance with RMP requirements, with prompt and appropriate responses following any finding and deficiencies identified during the audit.
Incident Investigation - Incidents that result in or could reasonably result in catastrophic releases of butane or propane will be investigated within 48 hours of an incident, and findings will be addressed promptly.
Employee Participation - The facility has a program for involvement of employees in conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other process safety management elements.
Hot Work Permit - Permits will be required and issued for hot work operations conducted on or near a butane or propane process.
Contractor Safety - The facility has a program to evaluate contractors and ensure that contractors are properly trained, informed of all hazards, and performing work in a safe manner.

Five-year Accident History
The Facility has not had accidents in the past five years.

Emergency Response Program

PR Energy is considered a non- responding facility as described in 2017 RMP Amendments Compliance Obligations. PR Energy expects community first responders to address a release and the employees are instructed to evacuate when release occurs. The facility will inform federal and state emergency response agencies about accidental releases, review and update the emergency response plan as appropriate and ensure that employees are informed of the changes to the emergency response plan.
